definitions.definition: to move using your legs, going faster than when you walk

examples.text: Can you run as fast as Mike?
They turned and ran when they saw us coming.
She **came running** to meet us.
I had to run to catch the bus.
The dogs ran off as soon as we appeared.
He ran home in tears to his mother.
The children spent the morning running around in the park.
She can run really fast.
John can run very fast.
He ran out of the house.
She ran quickly downstairs.
She turned and ran blindly down the street.
Alan was running for a bus when he slipped on some ice.
Billy turned the corner and ran headlong into Mrs Bradley.
They've seen us! Run for your life!
The boy went running off to get the ball.

definitions.definition: to travel a particular distance by running

examples.text: Who was the first person to run a mile in under four minutes?
I ran four miles today.

definitions.definition: to run as a sport

examples.text: She used to run when she was at college.
I often go running before work.
Try to run round the block a few times every morning.

definitions.definition: to take part in a race

examples.text: He will be running in the 100 metres tonight.
There are only five horses running in the first race.
to **run a marathon**
Farah **ran a** fine **race** to take the gold medal.

definitions.definition: to make a race take place

examples.text: The Derby will be run in spite of the bad weather.

definitions.definition: to hurry from one place to another

examples.text: I've spent the whole day running around after the kids.

definitions.definition: to be in charge of a business, campaign, etc.

examples.text: to run a hotel/store/language school
He has no idea how to **run a business**.
Stop trying to **run my life** *(= organize it)* for me.
The shareholders want more say in how the **company is run**.
a badly run company
Both candidates have **run a** good **campaign**.
state-run industries
The school is jointly run with the local parish.
He tried to run the restaurant himself, but soon got into financial difficulties.
It is a small, privately run hotel.
The office had never been so well run.
Who is running the event?

definitions.definition: to make a service, course of study, etc. available to people

examples.text: The college **runs **summer **courses** for foreign students.
The programme will be jointly run with NASA in the US.
The college runs several English classes for adults.
They ran a series of lectures on the subject.
Volunteer counsellors run a 24-hour helpline.

definitions.definition: to travel on a particular route

examples.text: Buses to Oxford run every half hour.
All the trains **are running late** *(= are leaving later than planned)*.
Trains between London and Brighton run throughout the day.
Local buses run regularly to and from the school.
He claimed that 95 per cent of trains run on time.
When does the London Underground stop running at night?

definitions.definition: to make buses, trains, etc. travel on a particular route

examples.text: They run extra trains during the rush hour.
The transport company is concerned about the cost of running more buses.

definitions.definition: to operate or function; to make something do this

examples.text: Stan had the chainsaw running.
Our van runs on *(= uses)* diesel.
Could you run the engine for a moment?
The engine was running very smoothly.
Our car only runs on unleaded petrol.

definitions.definition: when a computer program or system runs or somebody runs it, it operates

examples.text: You may find that some apps are running slowly.
There are too many programs running on your computer.
You need to have antivirus software running on your PC.
The app runs on all Android devices.
You can **run the program** overnight.
My PC runs Windows 10.
Don't forget to run a final spellcheck.
What **applications** were you **running** when the problem occurred?

definitions.definition: if a recording on a tape runs or somebody runs it, it plays

examples.text: He didn't know the tape was still running.
Run the tape, please.
Can you run the tape back a few minutes?

definitions.definition: to own and use a vehicle or machine

examples.text: I can't afford to run a car on my salary.

definitions.definition: to drive somebody to a place in a car

examples.text: Shall I run you home?
Would you mind running me to the shops?

definitions.definition: to move, especially quickly, in a particular direction

examples.text: The car ran off the road into a ditch.
A shiver ran down my spine.
The sledge ran smoothly over the frozen snow.
The old tramlines are still there but now no trams run on them.

definitions.definition: to move something in a particular direction

examples.text: She ran her fingers nervously through her hair.
I **ran my eyes over** the page.

definitions.definition: to lead or stretch from one place to another; to make something do this

examples.text: He had a scar running down his left cheek.
The road runs parallel to the river.
The railway line runs right past the house.
The bookcase runs the length of the room.
We ran a cable from the lights to the stage.

definitions.definition: to flow

examples.text: The tears ran down her cheeks.
Water was running all over the bathroom floor.

definitions.definition: to make liquid flow
definitions.sensetop: run something (into something)run something for somebodyrun somebody something

examples.text: She ran hot water into the bucket.
to **run the hot tap** *(= to turn it so that water flows from it)*
I'll **run a bath** for you.
I'll **run you a bath**.

definitions.definition: to send out a liquid

examples.text: Who left the tap running?
Your nose is running *(=  is flowing from it).
The smoke makes my eyes run.

definitions.definition: to be covered with a liquid

examples.text: His face was running with sweat.
The bathroom floor was running with water.

definitions.definition: if the colour runs in a piece of clothing, etc. when it gets wet, the colour comes out of the material and spreads into other pieces of clothing, etc. in the same water

examples.text: The colour ran and made all my underwear pink.

definitions.definition: to melt

examples.text: The wax began to run.

definitions.definition: to become different in a particular way, especially a bad way

examples.text: The river **ran dry** *(= stopped flowing)* during the drought.
Supplies are **running low**.
We understand that feelings are **running high** on this issue
We've **run short** of milk.
You've got your rivals **running scared**.

definitions.definition: to be at or near a particular level

examples.text: Inflation was running at 26 per cent.

definitions.definition: to continue for a particular period of time without stopping
definitions.sensetop: run for somethingrun from A to B

examples.text: Her last musical ran for six months on Broadway.
The course runs from June 25th to August 27th.
This debate will **run and run**!

definitions.definition: to operate or be legally acceptable for a particular period of time

examples.text: The permit runs for three months.
The lease on my house only has a year left to run.

definitions.definition: to happen or progress at the time or in the way mentioned

examples.text: Programmes are **running** a few minutes **behind schedule** this evening.
Everything is running according to plan.
Her life had always **run smoothly** before.
The murderer was given three life sentences, to run concurrently.

definitions.definition: to be a candidate in an election for a political position, especially in the US

examples.text: Obama ran a second time in 2012.
Hilary Clinton **ran for president** in 2016.
He ran unsuccessfully for the Senate in New York.
She is planning to run in the parliamentary election.

definitions.definition: to bring or take something into a country illegally and secretly

examples.text: He used to run guns across the border.
She made money by running drugs.

definitions.definition: to have particular words, contents, etc.

examples.text: Their argument ran something like this…
‘Ten shot dead by gunmen,’ ran the newspaper headline.

definitions.definition: to print and publish an item or a story

examples.text: On advice from their lawyers they decided not to run the story.

definitions.definition: to do a test, an experiment, etc.
definitions.sensetop: run a test, a check, an experiment, etc.run something on somethingrun something

examples.text: The doctors decided to run some more tests on the blood samples.
The two experiments are run in parallel.
The company is running clinical trials of the new drug.

definitions.definition: if tights or stockings run, a long thin hole appears in them
to be pleased to do what somebody wants

examples.text: She knew she had only to call and he would come running.

definitions.definition: to run in order to escape from somebody/something
to treat somebody badly and not worry about their feelings
working fully and correctly

examples.text: It will be a lot easier when we have the database up and running.
We soon had the sound system up and running.

wordOrigin: Old English rinnan, irnan (verb), of Germanic origin, probably reinforced in Middle English by Old Norse rinna, renna. The current form with -u- in the present tense is first recorded in the 16th cent.
